ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral Otitis Media with Effusion (OME) superimposed on Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of recent URI, 'plugged' sensation, significant air-bone gaps, and bilateral Type B tympanograms are classic signs of middle ear fluid.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Eustachian Tube Dysfunction
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Consistent with post-URI status and negative pressure development, but flat tympanograms strongly suggest progression to effusion.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To visually confirm the presence of middle ear effusion, air-fluid levels, or bubbles behind the tympanic membrane.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation indicates a temporary conductive pathology (OME) superimposed on the patient's known congenital sensorineural hearing loss, resulting in a mixed hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral mixed hearing loss. Underlying SNHL is mild-to-moderate (BC 30-55 dB HL). AC thresholds are moderately-severe to severe (60-75 dB HL) with a 30-35 dB air-bone gap.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral Type B (flat) tympanograms with normal ear canal volume, consistent with middle ear effusion.

tests.name: Wideband Acoustic Immittance (Reflectance)
tests.result_summary: High reflectance (near 100%) at low-to-mid frequencies, indicating a stiff, fluid-filled middle ear system.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Word recognition scores are fair to good (82% AD, 76% AS) when presented at high levels (100 dB HL) to overcome the conductive component.

proposed_items: Referral to physician (PCP or ENT) for treatment of Otitis Media with Effusion.
Monitor hearing status until conductive component resolves.
Temporary reduction in hearing aid use or gain adjustment may be necessary if feedback occurs or benefit is minimal due to fluid.
Referral to ENT or Primary Care Physician
counseling_actions: Explain that the 'plugged' feeling and hearing drop are likely due to fluid from the recent cold.
Reassure the parent that the underlying 'nerve' hearing appears stable and the current drop is likely temporary.
Discuss why hearing aids are currently less effective (fluid acts as a plug blocking sound).

escalation.rationale_short: To manage the middle ear fluid; not an emergency but requires medical attention to restore baseline hearing.

follow_up_plan.objective: Audiologic re-evaluation to confirm resolution of the conductive component (air-bone gap) and return to baseline sensorineural thresholds.

expected_outcome: Resolution of middle ear effusion with medical management or time.
Return of hearing thresholds to the baseline mild-to-moderate SNHL.
Restored effectiveness of current hearing aids.
